Expectation1: Teach children about Jewish traditions, values, and history
Situation1: The child's bar mitzvah is approaching, and they have not yet mastered the Torah portion.
Expectation2: Represent clients effectively in legal proceedings
Situation2: They appear at a minor hearing where the stakes are relatively low
Story: I sat at my desk, the Torah portion open in front of me, my son’s anxious face reflected in the window as dusk settled. His bar mitzvah was only weeks away, and he still stumbled over the Hebrew, his confidence wavering. As his parent, I felt the weight of tradition pressing on me—my responsibility to guide him, to ensure he understood not just the words, but the meaning behind them. My phone buzzed, pulling me back to my other world. A reminder: tomorrow’s hearing. It was a minor case, but my client was nervous, relying on me to represent them with the same dedication I gave to every case. I knew I should spend the evening preparing, reviewing notes, anticipating questions. But my son needed me, too. The expectations from both sides pressed in—my community, my family, my client, my profession. I felt torn, guilt gnawing at me no matter which way I leaned. I stared at the Torah, then at my legal pad, heart pounding, unsure which role to step into tonight.
